page.title: 09PLACE NAMES in Withington 2
page.content: shelter".{Hodge hill}O.E. hogg "a hog" {Withington Green, Smiths Green and {Harop Green}O.E. grene "a green" originally described the clearing in the wood in the 5th and 6th cent. It is a commonplace name suffix in once wooded areas. Many{farm names}have O.E.derivations. Deans Rough was Diglake O.E. dit, dic, lacu "watercourse ditch". Gorseyknowl O.E. gorstig cnoll "gorse on a knoll" (or hill). Shellmorehill Farm O.E. sceld mor hyll "moor at a shelter". Turnock Farm O.E. purnic, pornuc "thorny place" (may have Celtic origins) Spords Farm, Spodes Croft, from surname Spode. { Wood names}Rulow Wood O.E. ruh hlaw "rough mound". Willies Wood O.E. wilig wudu "willow wood". Burnt Acre, Brick Kiln Wood, The Bottoms, Mere Moss O.E. mere mos, "a pool""bog swamp".
